awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An Alaskan perspective on middle Paleozoic terrane translation, contraction, and subduction initiation in northwestern Laurentia
awd_abstract_narration:
A fundamental concept in plate tectonics is that ancient continental margins undergo a conversion process from “passive” zones of sediment accumulation to “active” zones dominated by subduction, volcanism, and mountain building. The process by which this transition occurs is through subduction initiation along continental margins. However, modern examples and numerical models of subduction initiation remain highly contentious. The late Paleozoic (ca. 450–300 million years ago) conversion of northwestern North America from a passive to an active margin is often cited as a classic example of this fundamental plate tectonic process, but very little is known about the nature and timing of key events in northern Alaska and Yukon, Canada, that led to this subduction initiation event. This study promotes collaboration between academic researchers at three U.S. institutions and government researchers at the United States Geological Survey (USGS) to better inform our understanding of late Paleozoic tectonic events in a remote and understudied region of North America. A diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students will participate in research initiatives at each institution. In addition, the research team will collaborate with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and the USGS to disseminate geologic knowledge of Arctic Alaska to the public, to enhance the economic competitiveness of the U.S. and facilitate the training of the next generation of Arctic Earth scientists.

Recent models for the middle Paleozoic tectonic evolution of North America (Laurentia) highlight margin-parallel transport of circum-Arctic terranes followed by widespread continental subduction initiation from the Yukon to Nevada. However, the timing, nature, and duration of middle Paleozoic orogenic events remain ambiguous. This project will focus on key structural relationships and unique Devonian–Carboniferous synorogenic sedimentary and magmatic rocks within the Arctic Alaska terrane of northern Alaska. The research consists of three major components: 1) the examination of synorogenic rocks coupled with the development of a regional provenance dataset; 2) a petrological, geochemical, and geochronological examination of regional Middle to Upper Devonian igneous rocks; and 3) a field-based structural study integrated with regional seismic datasets to reconstruct the style of Devonian–Carboniferous deformation in Arctic Alaska. This work will provide critical new insights into the Paleozoic tectonic evolution of northwestern North America and the greater circum-Arctic region to assess the viability of several subduction initiation mechanisms. In addition, this project will provide new piercing points for Mesozoic tectonic reconstructions of the Arctic, with relevance to several subdisciplines of the geosciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project focused on developing a better understanding of the tectonic and paleogeographic setting of the Arctic Alaska terrane and its role in late Paleozoic reconstructions of the circum-Arctic. The overarching goals were to (1) determine the age and tectonic setting of key Devonian- Carboniferous igneous and sedimentary units exposed in the central and northeastern Brooks Range through geological mapping combined with stratigraphic, geochronologic, geochemical and paleontological studies; and (2) establish the timing and nature of contractional deformation in units observed in the subsurface of northern Alaska that are coeval with those examined in the Brooks Range through seismic interpretation coupled with geochronology of drill core samples. Fieldwork for the project was conducted in multiple areas in the northeastern and central Brooks Range, Alaska during 2022-2024. The project involved two graduate students and 4 undergraduate students at the University of Iowa and mentoring and collaboration with a post-doctoral scholar, graduate student and several undergraduate students from Dartmouth College and Washington and Lee University.

Major research outcomes of the project include:

1) The Double Mountain complex in the northeastern Brooks Range is a ca. 373 Ma arc sequence that is correlative with slightly older Devonian arc units in Hammond and Coldfoot subterranes of the Arctic Alaska terrane in the central Brooks Range and coeval with widespread granitic magmatism the North Slope subterrane. The Devonian arc units collectively record subduction initiation on the northern Cordilleran margin of North America after the middle Paleozoic assembly of the Arctic Alaska terrane from multiple peri-Laurentian and peri-Baltic crustal fragments.

2) Clastic rocks of the Upper Devonian Beaucoup Formation in the central Brooks Range received detritus from arc-related units in North Slope, Coldfoot and Hammond subterranes of the Arctic Alaska terrane and were likely deposited in a back-arc basin setting.  

3) A prominent angular unconformity between Devonian and Mississippian rocks in the northeastern Brooks Range and repeated drowning of carbonate platform units in the central Brooks Range suggest that Devonian clastic strata of the Arctic Alaska terrane were deposited basin setting punctuated with contractional deformation rather than passive margin setting.

4) Deformation recorded in the subsurface of the North Slope, Alaska indicates a contractional setting for the North Slope subterrane that initiated between ca. 416–367 Ma and extended into Mississippian time.

The project fostered meaningful collaborations between several academic institutions (University of Iowa, Dartmouth College, Washington & Lee University) and government agencies (Alaska Division of Geologic and Geophysical Studies, U.S. Geological Survey). Significant opportunities in STEM training and education have been provided as well. University of Iowa personnel supported by the project include a M.S. student and undergraduate student from underrepresented groups, a Veteran M.S. student, and 3 female graduate and undergraduate students. Collaboration with field and geochronologic research of graduate and undergraduate students from Dartmouth College and Washington and Lee University has been provided by this project. The project supported publication of a peer-reviewed manuscript, eight public presentations at conferences and two M.S. thesis at the University of Iowa. The project produced 4 geologic maps and supporting analytical data from remote areas of the Brooks Range that are incorporated into state and federal mapping databases.


Last Modified: 08/11/2024
Modified by: William Mcclelland
